column4: I didn't get any warnings when I installed Ubuntu. Can you give an example?
not installing ubuntu, installing the nvidia X drivers for linux.
no
those are burried
it asks you whether to look for a precompiled module.  then it tells you it didn't find a precompiled module.
indeed.  I'm talking about doing it a different way because he didn't succeed in doing it that way.
I don't know why it failed.  dummkauf, what happens when you follow the howto?
Windows' *
why would you need the livecd to repair the root filesystem?
because you can't repair a file system while it is mounted
that admin console doesn't mount the filesystem AFAIK; that's why your /etc/fstab says "defaults,errors=remount-ro" for the options on the root fs. So you can repair it.
it's mounted read only, but it is still mounted

the reason you can't fsck a mounted filesystem is because the inodes are in use and the counts are wrong and all these things, and it closes files which can't be closed because they are open and corrupts everything. If you mount a filesystem readonly, it's still in virgin state. You can't fix a filesystem if you can't read it; the livecd mounts it readonly anyway.
the library is part of a debian package. It's set up properly.
the only way to get that error is if the library is not in the library path (or it isn't there in the first place, or it is damaged)
He's running an AMD64 system. If he has the wrong arch library, he'll get the same message.
true
I think he's knowlegable enough to have avoided that pitfall
I quote: "harrism: don't see a 64 bit version," That means that something, somewhere, is 32-bit.
actually I think he's running something that was linked against a different arch, or a different path.  remember that the library path can be compiled into the running binary
but you are probably correct, rereading what he said.
exactly, I think he's running a 32-bit mupen on a 64-bit system, which means his 32-bit mupen is looking for a 32-bit libsdl and finding a 64-bit it can't handle, causing that error.
